CatDescriptText: Mr. John Campbell, unemployed, Hill and Mr. Hardrick William, steel chipper, Hill, were part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, March 24, 1962, pg. 8 with question: "Do you think Pittsburgh Negroes are justified in being angry at the failure of city officials to appoint a Negro as police inspector, in spite of repeated appeals to grant them representation at this level of law enforcement?" Mr. Campbell's answer reads: "Yes, I'll go along with that, but the question you should be asking is how we can get the city to make some improvements on streets in the sections where Negroes live.  First, get some improvements in the slums, then worry about these other things."  Mrs. William's answer reads: "Of course.  I think if more Negroes would protest these things they would get more consideration."
TitMainTitle: Group portrait of John Campbell and Hardrick William, standing in front of row of stores and open car trunk
